Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Biological and Cultural Influences on Infant Stress Response Development

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research has established that there are a variety of biological and cultural factors that influence health outcomes and disparities. One of the major scientific challenges that remains is understanding how those factors change over time. This project takes up one such example in immigrant communities, who in the U.S. exhibit unique and somewhat paradoxical health trajectories. Initially their health profiles exceed expectations, but over time they decrease to mirror health disparity patterns found among U.S.-born populations. Typically, this has been theorized to be the product of acculturation and other environmental factors. In looking at differential psychological stress, this project, which trains a student in the methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, asks whether there might be a biological dimension to this, measurable by assessing the influence of maternal stress on infants' stress response development. Considerable research shows that the early emotional environment can have a significant influence on how infants develop. In assessing how mothers' feelings of stress can lead to altered development of infants' stress responses, the findings will be disseminated to organizations that seek to improve mothers' stress in ways that can have repercussions on the function and wellbeing of the next generation. The project will provide information on the types of resources or programs immigrant mothers may need to ameliorate stress in small communities around the country.

Elizabeth Holdsworth, under the supervision of Dr. Lawrence Schell of the State University of New York at Albany, will explore what factors contribute to physiological stress, particularly acculturative stress, among immigrant women, how the local ecological context is embodied in the experience of stress, and to what extent maternal stress is transmitted transgenerationally, influencing infant stress response development. This project will interview immigrant mothers of infants living in the Capital Region of New York State who moved to the U.S. within the past five years. Immigrant mothers will complete questionnaires about perceived stress, acculturative stress, and other topics, as well as participate in semi-structured interviews to provide more information on what immigrant mothers identify as their most significant challenges and struggles. These responses will be associated with amounts of cortisol in mothers' hair, a measure of chronic stress response activation over the past three months, to determine which stressors lead to the greatest chronic physical stress in immigrant mothers. Saliva samples will also be collected from immigrant mother's infants before and after an injected vaccination to assess the change in cortisol production, a measure of stress response reactivity. Infant stress response extent will also be associated with mothers' reports of stress to determine which factors have the greatest influence on infant stress response development. Lastly, the investigators of this project will participate in local community events and observe programs to determine what resources are available to and accessed by immigrant mothers in the area that could improve or exacerbate stress. The project will contribute to debates in biocultural anthropology and other fields about the co-occurrence of acculturative and other forms of stress, the influence of psychosocial stress on health disparities, the influence of local ecology on stress exposure, and the relationship between postnatal maternal stress on infant stress response.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under the guidance of Dr. Lawrence Schell (PI), Elizabeth Holdsworth (co-PI) conducted ethnographic and biological research among immigrant mothers of young children living in a rural region of New York State to identify which aspects of their lives they found stressful, and how the local environment unequally distributed that stress among women. The Co-PI conducted participant observation and interviews with community representatives in order to identify and describe the challenges and resources available for immigrant mothers living in this region and how these resources were accessed. The Co-PI recruited mother-child pairs and evaluated women's sources of stress and support through questionnaires and interviews. The Co-PI also collected small hair samples from the women to measure their cortisol hormone  levels (the "stress" hormone that indicates how frequently someone's body is experiencing a stress response) over the past three months, and child's saliva samples to measure how their own stress response is developing. The Co-PI also obtained access to a large longitudinal dataset to test some of these biological relationships in a larger sample.

This project identified the ways that social inequality can create unequal exposure to stress among immigrant women living in the US, in ways that shape health disease across generations. Much research on the ways that stress affects immigrant women's physiology has focused on acculturation and discrimination, with most explanations of how stress affects immigrant women's physiology focused on the individual person's responses and behaviors. This project used multiple levels of data, including individual (questionnaires and interviews) and structural (interviews with local organization representatives and participant observation), to identify the predominant stressors that affect women's production of cortisol (a marker of stress response activity), and describe how those stressors are shaped by the larger environment, particularly in a more rural environment. In particular, women's cortisol levels were mostly determined by negative experiences in childhood, and their negative living situations before moving to the mainland US. Moving to this rural region of the US, while it presented its own challenges, was a significant improvement for women's lives and especially for their children's lives and education, which was their first priority. For women that had spent most of their lives in this region, the main source of stress was lack of social activities and community, as well as a lack of transportation in the area. Many organizations that served immigrant women in the area described policy and funding restrictions on the people they were able to serve, and the ways they could address transportation challenges, resulting in access to resources patterned by residential location and wealth. As such, effects on women's stress physiology, which is associated with lifetime health and disease, are shaped by institutional and governmental policies regarding the distribution of resources within this rural community.

Additionally, this work significantly contributed to knowledge of how the broader environment shapes human physical growth and development. While previous research has found that the external social and emotional environment, particularly psychosocial stress, has been related to changes in child growth in height and weight, these relationships are not consistent across environments and the effects of past and current environments on growth are difficult to disentangle. Using a large longitudinal study (Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children, ALSPAC), the Co-PI found that changes in epigenetic programming of a stress responses-related gene (NR3C1) was associated with decreased height growth from birth to five years of age. This study was the first to identify changes in the epigenetic patterns of this gene to be associated with infancy and early childhood growth in height. These results indicate that the broader social and emotional environment may program children's neuroendocrine physiology associated with stress in ways that influence whole body physiology, including physical growth.

Extensive data was collected and accessed during the project, allowing for multiple future research projects on the determinants of stress among immigrant mothers in this region, the relationship of maternal stress to child epigenetic patterns of stress response-related genes, and other epigenetic contributors to child growth trajectories.

Throughout this project, the co-PI worked with a local community health task force to develop the study and report the results to representatives of relevant community organizations. This project allowed local community organizations to gain important information about the needs, challenges, and utilization of resources in the population they serve (immigrant families). Additionally, this project allowed for the extensive training of a woman scientist in research project design, implementation, data collection methods such as participant observation, interviewing, and collecting biological samples, qualitative and biostatistical analytic methods, and collaborative research methods with community members. This project is the basis for the co-PI's doctoral dissertation.
